transcripts.text: We make giant puppets and masks and shadows and stilts and just about anything else we can think of.

Puppeteering as a job is really great.  I love getting messy and working with lots of people.  I think there's something about working together with their hands.  that for some reason nowadays is a fairly novel feeling.
I was real excited when I first heard from Greenpeace.  For me, it is kind of a perfect alignment of what I'm passionate about when it comes to what I want to do with my art.

Greenpeace asked us to give them ideas about what we could create in terms of some sort of a creature or being that would represent the trash in the oceans.  So to create a monster, we said, well, let's have one with a giant mouth that just has always wanted to eat, but then is also regurgitating this plastic.

Nice.  At least it burped.  We made it sort of have some elements to it that would remind whoever sees it that it kind of came from the ocean.  So it has almost a bit of an angler fish kind of feel to the mouth and big bulging eyes like a deep sea creature of some kind.  I think of it as hungry, but at the same time, it can't keep anything down.  So it has like a continual sickness.  So it's a really pitiable kind of creature.

It has arms and it's got a mouth and it regurgitates plastic and we want the eyeballs to rotate around and all these ideas.  But then to actually put it into play and try to figure out how to make it work.

Oh yeah.  I mean there's always engineering challenges in a lot of what we build.  We try things out if it's a new puppet, which this puppet has never been made before.  So each one has its own unique set of challenges.  That's better.  I like transforming everyday objects that we just sort of overlook, that's so simple to not think about.  Straws, just kind of taking some of those and transforming them into things that remind us of the natural world.  There's just something about that that is like a sweet spot for me.  When I do my work well, I go to a place, a performance, and I see people get activated in a way where they're believing that some creature or some story is coming to life in a very real way for them.

I always feel like every corporation should have to deal with all the stuff that they create.  And so to create a monster that's there to deliver that plastic back to the corporation seems only fitting to be able to like, here it is.
